title.narrative: Provision of life saving first-line primary emergency health services to IDPs and conflict affected communities in South Ninewa and North Salah al-Din areas.

description.narrative:
The overall objective of the project is to provide free life-saving integrated primary health care services to newly displaced and critically at risk population in South Ninewa and North Salah al-Din areas. The activities will be implemented by running Mobile Medical Teams (MMTs) ensuring the availability of essentials medicines (provided in kind by WHO) assuring outreach health services through the networks of community health workers (CHWs) ensuring availability of a comprehensive package of primary health care services and referrals in the above areas.
This proposal aims at ensuring the service provisions of an essential package of primary health services which started in December 2016 in the framework of the IHPF – 2016 Second Standard Allocation. The current on-going project is going to end the 09 June 2016 –therefore, this proposal aims at ensuring the support to the 2 existing MMTs, which are deployed in South Ninewa (Qayyara district) and North Salah al Din (Shirqat district). The targeted areas have been identified in close coordination with DoH Ninewa and DoH Salah al Din, to reach underserved pocket of vulnerable conflict affected populations (IDPs, returnees and remainees) who, without the services provided by the MMCs, will be in danger of being left without essential health services. An increased number of IDPs is expected to settle in the next weeks in the retaken areas/villages in Shirqat district, as many people still living on the East bank of the river (still under ISIL control) are already fleeing the city to seek safety. Therefore, new displacements are expected in the areas of operation, where the small static facilities available cannot cope with the needs.
In addition, INTERSOS has also secured funds from UNFPA in order to deploy 2 Reproductive Health Mobile Unit (RHMU) in the same areas of the MMTs – the 2 interventions are designed to be implemented in strong complementarity, as a dedicated van managed only by female medical staff (doctor and nurses) is more adapted to the specific cultural context.
